description: From Middle English til, from Northern Old English til, from or akin to Old Norse til (‚Äúto, till‚Äù); both from Proto-Germanic *til (‚Äúto, toward‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *tilƒÖ (‚Äúplanned point in time‚Äù). Not a shortening of until; rather, until comes from till with the prefix un- (‚Äúagainst; toward; up to‚Äù) also found in unto. Cognate with Old Frisian til (‚Äúto, till‚Äù), Danish til (‚Äúto‚Äù), Swedish till (‚Äúto, till‚Äù), Icelandic til (‚Äúto, till‚Äù). Also related to Old English til (‚Äúgood‚Äù), German Ziel (‚Äúgoal‚Äù), Gothic êçÑêåπêåª (til, ‚Äúsomething fitting or suitable‚Äù).

entries.meaning: Until; to, up to; as late as (a given time).
examples: She stayed till the very end.
I have to work till eight o'clock tonight.
They led him till his tent
And then she changed her voice and would be as saft as honey: 'My puir wee Ailie, was I thrawn till ye? Never mind, my bonnie. You and me are a' that's left, and we maunna be ill to ither.'
VLADIMIR: Together again at last! We'll have to celebrate this. But how? (He reflects.) Get up till I embrace you.

description: From Middle English tylle (‚Äútill‚Äù), possibly from Middle English tillen (‚Äúto draw‚Äù) from Old English *tyllan (‚Äúto draw, attract‚Äù) (as in betyllan (‚Äúto lure, decoy‚Äù) and fortyllan (‚Äúto draw away‚Äù); related to *tollian > Middle English tollen). Cognate with Albanian ndjell (‚ÄúI lure, attract‚Äù).
Alternatively, Middle English tylle is from Anglo-Norman tylle (‚Äúcompartment‚Äù), from Old French tille (‚Äúcompartment, shelter on a ship‚Äù), from Old Norse √æilja (‚Äúplank‚Äù).

entries.meaning: A removable box within a cash register containing the money.
examples: Pull all the tills and lock them in the safe.

entries.meaning: The contents of a cash register, for example at the beginning or end of the day or of a cashier's shift.
examples: My count of my till was 30 dollars short.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A tray or drawer in a chest.

description: From Middle English tilyen, from Old English tilian.

verbs.description: till (third-person singular simple present tills, present participle tilling, simple past and past participle tilled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To develop so as to improve or prepare for usage; to cultivate (said of knowledge, virtue, mind etc.).
(transitive) To work or cultivate or plough (soil); to prepare for growing vegetation and crops.

description: Unknown, but possibly via etymology 3 (the verb) because alluvial deposit is used as a fertilizer.

entries.meaning: glacial drift consisting of a mixture of clay, sand, pebbles and boulders
(dialect) manure or other material used to fertilize land

description: From Middle English tylle; shortened from lentile (English lentil).
